title: Beatty Saugeen River
text:
The Beatty Saugeen River is a <a href="river">river</a> in the <a href="Saugeen%20River">Saugeen River</a> and <a href="Lake%20Huron">Lake Huron</a> <a href="drainage%20basin">drainage basin</a>s in <a href="Grey%20County%2C%20Ontario">Grey County</a>, <a href="Southwestern%20Ontario">southwestern</a> <a href="Ontario">Ontario</a>, <a href="Canada">Canada</a>. It is a tributary of the South Saugeen River.
Course.
The river begins in a <a href="Forest">woods</a> southeast of the community of <a href="Boothville%2C%20Ontario">Boothville</a> in the township of <a href="Southgate%2C%20Ontario">Southgate</a>. It flows west, to the north of the community of <a href="Dromore%2C%20Ontario">Dromore</a>, then southwest, passing to the north of the community of <a href="Yeovil%2C%20Ontario">Yeovil</a>. The river heads west, over Holstein Dam at the community of <a href="Holstein%2C%20Ontario">Holstein</a>, and under <a href="Ontario%20Highway%206">Ontario Highway 6</a> south of the community of <a href="Orchardville%2C%20Ontario">Orchardville</a>. The Beatty Saugeen turns northwest, passing to the south of the community of <a href="Hampden%2C%20Ontario">Hampden</a> in the township of <a href="West%20Grey%2C%20Ontario">West Grey</a>, before reaching its mouth at the South Saugeen River on the south side of the town of Hanover.
The river is about long with a drainage basin of and average gradient of 4.5 metres per kilometre (23.8 ft per mile).
Geology.
The headwaters of the river are in the Dundalk <a href="Till%20plain">Till plain</a>, and the remainder of the river in the Horseshoe <a href="Moraine">Moraine</a> and the Teeswater <a href="Drumlin%20field">Drumlin field</a>.
Ecology.
There are four monitoring stations in the Beatty Saugeen drainage basin: two for <a href="Benthic%20zone">Benthic zone</a> animals, one for surface water quality, and one combined. There are two rare species: the Delta-spotted spiketail and the <a href="Asplenium%20scolopendrium">Hart's Tongue Fern</a>.
